feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: A flood watch has been issued for these areas. Please see that statement for more information on the rainfall and possible flooding.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued December 3 at 1:18AM CST until December 4 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...Kenedy Island, Willacy Island and Cameron Island Counties.
* WHEN...Through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kenedy Island; Willacy Island; Cameron Island

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued December 3 at 2:10AM EST until December 4 at 4:00AM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A strong, southward-flowing longshore current is forecast to develop at all central Florida Atlantic beaches today, along with a moderate risk for dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...Coastal Volusia, Coastal Brevard, Coastal Indian River, Coastal Saint Lucie, and Coastal Martin counties.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...The southward-flowing current could pull swimmers into deeper water, making them more susceptible to dangerous rip currents. This will also generate strong rip currents near piers, jetties, and reefs.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Volusia; Coastal Indian River; Coastal St. Lucie; Coastal Martin; Mainland Northern Brevard; Northern Brevard Barrier Islands; Mainland Southern Brevard; Southern Brevard Barrier Islands

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE TONIGHT

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued December 3 at 2:05AM EST until December 4 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A hard freeze with temperatures as low as 24 expected.
* WHERE...Portions of southeast Alabama and south central and southwest Georgia.
* WHEN...From 1 AM EST /midnight CST/ to 9 AM EST /8 AM CST/ Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coffee; Dale; Henry; Quitman; Clay; Randolph; Calhoun; Terrell; Dougherty; Lee; Worth; Early; Baker

cap:parameter.value: FREEZE WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM EST /MIDNIGHT CST/ TO 9 AM EST /8 AM CST/ WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued December 2 at 9:58PM AKST until December 3 at 9:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Heavy rainfall across the southern panhandle has resulted in minor flooding near the Thorne River. Rainfall rates will continue to diminish through late Monday, before picking back up again early Tuesday.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Thorne River near Areas Around The Thorne River Bridge.
* WHEN...Until 900 PM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 956 PM AKST, river gauge reports indicate rises in water levels from heavy rain in areas around the Thorne River bridge. Minor flooding is ongoing, especially near Thorne River. Over 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible.
- For Thorne River near Thorne Bay: At 7:00pm the stage was 13.6 feet. Flood Stage is 12.5 feet.
Impacts: At 12.5 feet: Water will begin to flow over the road upstream from the Thorne River bridge.
At 14.5 feet: 3 to 4 ft of water will be over the road upstream from the Thorne River bridge.

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued December 3 at 1:56AM EST until December 3 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 32.
* WHERE...Coastal Nassau and Eastern Marion Counties.
* WHEN...Until 9 AM EST this morning.
* IMPACTS...Appropriate action should be taken to ensure tender vegetation and outdoor pets have adequate protection from the cold temperatures. Young children, the elderly and the homeless are especially vulnerable to the cold. Take measures to protect them.

cap:parameter.value: FREEZE WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 AM EST THIS MORNING

* WHERE...Trout River County.
* WHEN...From 5 AM to 9 AM EST this morning.

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued December 3 at 12:01AM CST until December 4 at 12:00AM CST by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:

* WHERE...Southern Cook County. This includes the Tribal Lands of the Grand Portage Reservation. Highest accumulations will be on the higher elevations.
* WHEN...From this afternoon through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday evening commute.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 3 at 12:56AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary: An area of flurries and snow showers is moving across the North Carolina Piedmont this morning. While most areas will only see flurries, some locations will see a brief period of light snow accumulate to a dusting on elevated and grassy surfaces. A few isolated areas could see a brief burst of moderate snow, with accumulations up to an inch possible. The most likely areas to see accumulating snowfall will be north of the city of Charlotte. The snow and flurries are expected to end around daybreak. With temperatures expected to fall to the lower-to-mid 20s later this morning, any lingering wet or snow-covered roads are likely to freeze, resulting in isolated slick spots, especially on bridges and overpasses.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Alexander; Iredell; Davie; Catawba; Rowan; Cleveland; Lincoln; Gaston; Mecklenburg; Cabarrus; Union; Greater Caldwell; Greater Burke

cap:parameter.value: BRIEF PERIOD OF LIGHT SNOW OR FLURRIES THIS MORNING

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued December 2 at 9:47PM PST until December 3 at 12:00PM PST by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor tidal overflow expected.
* WHERE...Beaches of San Diego County and Orange County.
* WHEN...Through Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Minor tidal overflow during astronomical high tides around 6 feet Tuesday morning could inundate low lying locations, including parking lots. At highest risk are Imperial Beach, La Jolla Shores, Del Mar, Cardiff, Newport Beach, Sunset Beach and Seal Beach.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Time and height of highest tides each day:
Newport Beach - Tuesday: 6.01 feet at 916 AM.
La Jolla - Tuesday: 5.96 feet at 912 AM.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Diego County Coastal Areas; Orange County Coastal

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 8:22PM AKST until December 3 at 6:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW CONTINUES MONDAY NIGHT FOR THE NORTHERN INNER CHANNELS...
Heavy snow continues for the Haines and Skagway areas. As temperatures slowly warm aloft, a period of freezing rain is expected.
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations of 1 to 4 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Municipality of Skagway.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow will continue through Monday night with temperatures rising very slowly. A period of freezing rain is likely before the snow fully transitions to rain on Tuesday.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued December 2 at 8:22PM AKST until December 3 at 6:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW CONTINUES MONDAY NIGHT FOR THE NORTHERN INNER CHANNELS...
Heavy snow continues for the Haines and Skagway areas. As temperatures slowly warm aloft, a period of freezing rain is expected.
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches.
* WHERE...Haines Borough and Klukwan.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow will continue through Monday night for the upper portions of the Chilkat Valley. Freezing rain has been reported along Mud Bay as of 8pm Monday and will spread over Haines overnight before surface temperatures warm above freezing on Tuesday.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued December 2 at 9:52PM MST until December 3 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...West winds 30 to 40 mph, with gusts up to 60 mph over the high plains and 75 mph along the immediate eastern slopes of the Rocky Mountain Front.
* WHERE...Southern Rocky Mountain Front and adjacent foothills and plains, and Eastern Glacier, Western Toole, and Central Pondera Counties.
* WHEN...Until 11 AM MST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most intense period of winds are expected to occur from now through 6 AM MST Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Glacier, Western Toole, and Central Pondera; Southern Rocky Mountain Front; Southern High Plains

entry.summary:

* WHEN...Until 11 AM MST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued December 2 at 7:50PM AKST until December 3 at 11:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Another round of heavy rain will move into the central and southern panhandle early Tuesday morning along with warming temperatures. This may expand localized flooding.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...The following areas, Prince of Wales and Southern Inner Channels. This includes the cities of Craig, Klawock, Hydaburg, Coffman Cove, Thorne Bay, Ketchikan, and Metlakatla.
* WHEN...From 1 AM AKST Tuesday through Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, other low-lying areas and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain. Flooding may occur in poor drainage areas.
Emergency Managers report that a small slide occurred sometime late Sunday night near Carlanna Creek in Ketchikan. Officials request that you immediately call in any unusual activity on hillsides.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Rainfall amounts over the southern panhandle Sunday through Monday afternoon have been 3 to 6 inches with localized amounts of around 10 inches in the Ketchikan area.
Heavy rain will move back into the region early Tuesday morning. New rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches with localized amounts of up to 4 inches are expected through Tuesday evening. Additionally, freezing levels will rise to above 8,000 feet Tuesday morning.
Strong wind gusts of around 45 mph are also likely during this timeframe.
- Storm drains should be kept clear of debris as much as possible.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM AKST TUESDAY THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued December 2 at 7:50PM AKST until December 3 at 11:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Another round of heavy rain will move into the central and southern panhandle early Tuesday morning along with warming temperatures. This may expand localized flooding.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt is possible.
* WHERE...The following areas, Southern Inner Channels and Central Inner Channels. This includes the cities of Gustavus, Juneau, Petersburg, Kake, Port Alexander, Wrangell, And Hyder.
* WHEN...From 1 AM AKST Tuesday through Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, other low-lying areas and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain. Flooding may occur in poor drainage areas.
Heavy rain falling on the existing snowpack will lead to increased runoff. Rain falling on the hard pack snow will lead to icy conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Rainfall amounts since the change over from snow have been 1 to 2 inches for Juneau, Gustavus, and Kake, upwards of 3 inches in Petersburg and Wrangell, and lesser amounts so far in Hyder.
Heavy rain will move back into the region through early Tuesday morning. New rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches expected through Tuesday evening. Additionally, freezing levels will rise to around 6,000 feet Tuesday afternoon.
- Storm drains should be kept clear of debris as much as possible.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; City of Hyder

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM AKST TUESDAY THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Freezing Fog Advisory issued December 2 at 8:45PM PST until December 3 at 11:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Visibility one quarter mile or less in freezing fog.
* WHERE...In California, Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties. In Nevada, Northern Washoe County, Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake, and Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area.
* WHEN...Until 11 AM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous, especially along Highway 447 from Pyramid Lake to Gerlach, Highway 395 through the Honey Lake Valley from the CA-NV state line to Susanville, and Highways 36 and 44 around Susanville. Roads may also be slick.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Areas of freezing fog may expand into parts of the Reno-Sparks vicinity and from Pyramid Lake southward to Fernley by early Tuesday morning, with the highest potential for fog in these areas between 4 and 10 AM.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

cap:parameter.value: FREEZING FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM PST TUESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 11:45PM EST by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary: Light snow will taper to flurries during the early morning hours of Tuesday. Fluffy snow accumulations of a dusting to one half inch can be expected on the deep valley floors, with between 1 and 2 inches above 2,500 feet. If traveling over the higher elevations into Tuesday morning, slow down, use caution, and be prepared for slippery spots. Impacted high-elevation highways include US-421, US-119 and US-23 on Pine Mountain, and KY-160 and KY-179 on Big Black Mountain and also KY-74 over the Log Mountains.

cap:parameter.value: Light Snowfall Wrapping Up Across the Mountains of Southeast Kentucky Early Overnight

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 11:40PM EST by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary: Well below freezing temperatures may result in slick spots on area roads and on bridges/overpasses, in particular. Late night and early morning travellers should use caution, slow down, and allow for extra braking distance.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 11:27PM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches possible across the far northeast portion of the county near Euclid, Richmond Heights, and Mayfield. Accumulations quickly decrease to 1 inch or less across the rest of the county.
* WHERE...Cuyahoga County.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday morning commute.

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 2 at 11:27PM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations between 2 and 4 inches, with locally up to 6 inches across northern portions of the county.
* WHERE...Crawford County.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday morning commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A potent cold front will move through Wednesday night, ushering in strong, gusty winds and impactful lake effect snow Wednesday night through Thursday night. Additional winter weather headlines may be needed for that period.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 2 at 11:27PM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations of 3 to 6 inches in northern Geauga County and 1 to 3 inches in southern Geauga County.
* WHERE...Geauga County.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday morning commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A potent cold front will move through Wednesday night, ushering in strong, gusty winds and impactful lake effect snow Wednesday night into Thursday. Additional winter weather headlines may be needed for that period.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 2 at 11:27PM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations between 2 and 5 inches, with locally up to 6 inches in the most persistent squalls.
* WHERE...Ashtabula Inland, Ashtabula Lakeshore, and Lake Counties.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday morning commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A potent cold front will move through Wednesday night, ushering in strong, gusty winds and impactful lake effect snow Wednesday night into Thursday. Additional winter weather headlines may be needed for that period.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 2 at 11:27PM EST until December 3 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations between 4 and 10 inches for much of the county, but with locally up to 15 inches across eastern portions of the county.
* WHERE...Northern Erie and Southern Erie Counties.
* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. Travel could be difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday morning and evening commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A potent cold front will move through Wednesday night, ushering in strong, gusty winds and impactful lake effect snow Wednesday night through Thursday night. The combination of snow and blowing snow may create significant travel impacts, and additional winter weather headlines will likely be needed for this period.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Freezing Fog Advisory issued December 2 at 8:14PM PST until December 3 at 11:00AM PST by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Freezing Fog Advisory, visibility one quarter mile or less in areas of dense freezing fog. For the Air Stagnation Advisory, light winds and limited air movement will lead to a period of stagnant air conditions. This scenario could result in the build up of air pollutants over time.
* WHERE...West Central Willamette Valley.
* WHEN...For the Freezing Fog Advisory, until 11 AM PST Tuesday. For the Air Stagnation Advisory, until 4 AM PST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Deteriorating air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems. Low visibility in areas of dense freezing fog could make driving conditions hazardous.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Frost is possible on elevated surfaces and grassy surfaces, as well as bridges and overpasses.

cap:parameter.value: FREEZING FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM PST TUESDAY... ...AIR STAGNATION ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM PST THURSDAY

entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Freezing Fog Advisory, visibility one quarter mile or less in areas of dense freezing fog. For the Air Stagnation Advisory, light winds and limited air movement will lead to a period of stagnant air conditions. This scenario could result in the build up of air pollutants over time.
* WHERE...South Willamette Valley, and East Central Willamette Valley.
* WHEN...For the Air Stagnation Advisory, until 4 AM PST Thursday. For the Freezing Fog Advisory, until 11 AM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Deteriorating air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems. Low visibility in areas of dense freezing fog could make driving conditions hazardous.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Dense fog will impact portions of the I-5 corridor from Salem to Eugene. Frost is possible on elevated surfaces and grassy surfaces, as well as bridges and overpasses.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Central Willamette Valley; Benton County Lowlands; Linn County Lowlands; Lane County Lowlands

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 9:57PM EST by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
entry.summary:
WEATHER...
* A band of lake effect snow reaches the tip of the Thumb shortly after midnight and then moves southward toward Port Sanilac during the late night.
* Widely varying snowfall is expected to range from minor accumulation toward M-53 to near 4 inches along the shoreline from Port Austin to Harbor Beach.
* Peak coverage and intensity is projected from 2 AM to 5 AM followed by an offshore trend by sunrise.
IMPACTS...
* Visibility will likely be reduced to less than a quarter mile and could drop briefly to near zero at times. Rapid fluctuations of visibility will occur.
* Rapid accumulation will lead to slower travel conditions, especially along M-25 near the shoreline.

cap:parameter.value: A BAND OF LAKE EFFECT SNOW WILL GRAZE THE LAKE HURON SHORELINE WITH BURSTS OF HEAVY SNOW A TIMES LATE TONIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 9:47PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
Snow showers are ongoing across the North Carolina counties along the Tennessee border and will continue overnight. Light accumulations of 1 to 3 inches, with locally higher amounts of 3-5 inches at elevations above 3500 feet are expected by daybreak Tuesday when snow showers taper off. Gusty northwest winds are also expected but should remain below 35 mph across most locations.
Slow down and use caution if traveling across the higher elevations tonight through Tuesday morning. Snow covered roadways across the higher terrain could impact travel conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Avery; Madison; Yancey; Mitchell; Swain; Haywood; Graham

cap:parameter.value: Snow Ongoing Across the Smoky Mountains and North Carolina- Tennessee Border

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 8:18PM CST by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
Light snow has ended across the region. However, temperatures have fallen below freezing and are expected to drop into the teens to around 20 degrees by Tuesday morning. Lingering moisture on area roads will lead to icy patches, especially on bridges and overpasses.
Please use caution if traveling during this time period. Drivers should slow down and leave extra space between vehicles.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 5:13PM AKST until December 4 at 5:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation. Total ice accumulations of a glaze to one tenth of an inch and snow accumulations of up to 3 inches. North winds gusting 35 to 50 mph, strongest near the coast.
* WHERE...Bristol Bay.
* WHEN...Until 5 PM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Power outages are possible. Travel could be extremely hazardous.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Multiple rounds of light precipitation will bring chances for freezing rain. The first round, through Tuesday morning, will bring chances for a trace to a few hundredths of an inch of ice mixed in with light snow. Another round of precipitation Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday brings higher chances and greater amounts of freezing rain. The highest likelihood for freezing rain and ice accumulation will occur along a line roughly from Dillingham north through Koliganek, in the area east of the Ahklun Mountains. Temperatures are expected to rise above freezing and switch precipitation to plain rain from east to west on Wednesday as winds at the surface shift southeast.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 5:13PM AKST until December 5 at 3:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation expected. Total snow accumulations of up to one inch and ice accumulations of around a trace. Winds gusting 20 to 40 mph, strongest near the coast.
* WHERE...Kuskokwim Delta.
* WHEN...From 3 AM Tuesday to 3 PM AKST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Multiple rounds of light precipitation moving from south to north will increase chances for freezing rain. Tuesday precipitation is expected to hit and miss with light snow and freezing drizzle more likely near the Kuskokwim mountains to about the Kuskokwim River. Additional moisture will move through the area beginning Wednesday morning, increasing the likelihood for freezing rain near the coast of the Kuskokwim Delta, especially south of the Kuskokwim River. Northerly winds through the Kuskokwim River will keep temperatures near the surface well below freezing and Bethel cannot be ruled out for at least a glaze of ice Tuesday through Thursday.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 3 AM TUESDAY TO 3 PM AKST THURSDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 5:13PM AKST until December 5 at 3:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation expected. Total snow accumulations of up to 3 inches and ice accumulations of a glaze to one tenth of an inch.
* WHERE...Lower Kuskokwim Valley.
* WHEN...From noon Tuesday to 3 PM AKST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Light snow is expected across much of the area, though multiple rounds of light precipitation moving from south to north will increase chances for freezing rain. The highest likelihood for freezing rain will be east of Aniak, though Aniak cannot be ruled out for at least a glaze of ice. Chances for precipitation is expected to decrease Thursday afternoon.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM NOON TUESDAY TO 3 PM AKST THURSDAY

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued December 2 at 3:13PM AKST until December 4 at 7:45AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Record heavy rainfall on top of recent snowfall has resulted in minor flooding in the Ward Cover recreational area.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Ward Lake near Areas Near The Ward Lake Recreational Area.
* WHEN...Until 745 AM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 312 PM AKST, the dam operator reported heavy rain in areas near the Ward Lake recreational area. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly, especially near Ward Lake. Between 5 and 10 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 2 to 5 inches are possible.
- For Lake Connell Dam: At 7:30am the stage was 253.0 feet. Flood Stage is 252.0 feet.
Impacts: At 252.0 feet: 2 feet of water will be going over the emergency spillway which will produce minor flooding of areas around the Ward Lake recreation area with trails and Last Chance campground being inundated.

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 745 AM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 3:08PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Rain is expected to continue through Monday night followed by another round of heavy rain for Tuesday. 2 to 3 inches of rain is expected Monday afternoon through Tuesday night in the Hyder area.
Due to significant snow pack from the recent storm and frozen ground from recent cold temperatures, runoff will have a difficult time keeping up with this amount of rain. Expect ponding of water on roadways. Snow removal will become more difficult due to higher water content making the snow heavier. Boat owners should check on their vessels. Additionally, areas of compact snow will become very slippery.
Please let the National Weather Service office know if you are seeing impacts from this rainfall.

cap:parameter.value: RAIN ON SNOW CREATING HAZARDOUS CONDITIONS

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 3:08PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Over the last 12 hours, since the transition from snow, over half an inch rain has fallen between Angoon and Gustavus and 1 inch in the Juneau area.
Rain is expected to continue through Monday night followed by another round of heavy rain for Tuesday. 1 to 3 inches of rain is expected Monday afternoon through Tuesday night.
Due to significant snow pack from the recent storm and frozen ground from recent cold temperatures, runoff will have a difficult time keeping up with this amount of rain. Expect ponding of water on roadways and for some creeks to spike up. Snow removal will become more difficult due to higher water content making the snow heavier. Boat owners should check on their vessels. Additionally, areas of compact snow will become very slippery.
Please let the National Weather Service office know if you are seeing impacts from this rainfall.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau

cap:parameter.value: RAIN ON SNOW CREATING HAZARDOUS CONDITIONS

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 3:08PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Over the last 36 hours, portions of the southern panhandle have seen significant rainfall accumulations of over 3 inches, ranging to around 9 inches in parts of Ketchikan.
After a short-lived lull in the rain Monday night, another round of heavy rain is expected for Tuesday. Rainfall totals through Tuesday are expected to be 1 to 3 inches, with up to 4 inches in Ketchikan and Annette Island.
Runoff will have a difficult time keeping up with this amount of rain, particularly in areas where the ground froze over the last week. Expect ponding of water on roadways and for flashy creeks to spike up. Boat owners should check on their vessels.
Additionally, each round of heavy rain will have strong winds with gusts greater than 40 mph likely.
Please let the National Weather Service office know if you are seeing impacts from this rainfall.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: HEAVY RAIN AND STRONG WIND EXPECTED TO CONTINUE

* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Poor air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 2:30PM AKST until December 4 at 12:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blowing snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 10 inches. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph. Visibility reduced to one half mile.
* WHERE...Thompson Pass.
* WHEN...From 12 PM Tuesday to 12 AM AKST Wednesday night.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility to one half mile or less for extended periods of time.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM NOON TUESDAY TO MIDNIGHT AKST TUESDAY NIGHT FOR THOMPSON PASS

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 2:30PM AKST until December 4 at 3:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Freezing rain expected. Total ice accumulations of a light glaze.
* WHERE...Anchorage.
* WHEN...6 AM Tuesday to 3 AM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Difficult travel conditions are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Pockets of light freezing rain/drizzle are expected to develop Tuesday morning and continue throughout the day Tuesday. The best chance for ice accumulations will be in south and west Anchorage. Temperatures will rise above freezing Tuesday night, but rain can still freeze when hitting cold road and sidewalk surfaces.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM TUESDAY TO 3 AM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 2:30PM AKST until December 4 at 6:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Freezing rain expected. Total ice accumulations of a light glaze.
* WHERE...Western Kenai Peninsula.
* WHEN...6 AM Tuesday to 6 AM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Difficult travel conditions are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Pockets of light freezing rain/drizzle are expected to develop Tuesday morning and continue throughout the day Tuesday into Tuesday night. Temperatures will rise above freezing by Wednesday morning, but rain can still freeze when hitting cold road and sidewalk surfaces.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM TUESDAY TO 6 AM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 2:30PM AKST until December 5 at 3:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Freezing rain expected. Total ice accumulations of up to a few hundredths of an inch.
* WHERE...Susitna Valley.
* WHEN...From 3 PM Tuesday to 3 AM AKST Thursday
* IMPACTS...Difficult travel conditions are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Pockets of light freezing rain/drizzle are then expected to develop Tuesday afternoon and continue through Tuesday night into the day Wednesday. The best chance for ice accumulations will be west of the Parks Highway, but a glaze of ice is still possible in Talkeetna and and Willow. Precipitation may start as snow along the Alaska Range, particularly in Skwentna, with little to no snow accumulation expected.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 3 PM TUESDAY TO 3 AM AKST THURSDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued December 2 at 12:01PM AKST until December 4 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast.
* WHEN...From Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Plan on difficult travel conditions. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 45 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 11:59AM AKST until December 3 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blowing snow expected. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph will reduce visibility to one half mile or less at times.
* WHERE...Dalton Highway Summits.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on hazardous travel conditions. Areas of blowing snow will significantly reduce visibility. Expect areas of significant drifting snow on the roadway. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 40 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 2 at 3:53PM EST until December 3 at 7:00PM EST by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations between 3 and 9 inches, with highest additional amounts north of Route 6.
* WHERE...Warren County.
* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning commutes.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 2 at 3:53PM EST until December 3 at 7:00PM EST by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations between 3 and 8 inches, with highest additional amounts north of Route 6.
* WHERE...McKean County.
* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning commutes.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 3:12PM EST by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary: Snow will develop across southeast Kentucky this evening and fall for several hours before tapering to flurries during the early morning hours on Tuesday. Fluffy snow accumulations of a dusting to one half inch can be expected on the deep valley floors, increasing to between 1 and 2 inches above 2,500 feet. If traveling over the higher elevations this evening into Tuesday morning, slow down and use caution and be prepared for slippery spots. Impacted high-elevation highways include US-421, US-119 and US-23 on Pine Mountain, and KY-160 and KY-179 on Big Black Mountain and KY-74 over the Log Mountains.

cap:parameter.value: Light Snowfall Expected Across Mountains of Southeast Kentucky Tonight

entry.title: Frost Advisory issued December 2 at 2:21PM EST until December 3 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures as low as 33 will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...Inland Volusia and Northern Lake.
* WHEN...From 4 AM to 9 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

cap:parameter.value: FROST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 4 AM TO 9 AM EST TUESDAY
